Text:
Step 1: Think about how to explain 'nutrition' to someone reading at the Middle School level.
Step 2: Select appropriate vocabulary and sentence structure.
Step 3: Write a paragraph of 200 words that follows your plan. Use your knowledge of nutrition to make sure the paragraph is accurate.

Nutrition is the science of how our bodies use food to stay healthy. When we eat, our bodies break down the food into tiny parts, like nutrients. These nutrients give our bodies energy to move, grow, and work. They also help our immune system fight off sickness. There are six main types of nutrients: carbohydrates, proteins, fats, vitamins, minerals, and water. Carbohydrates give us the most energy. Proteins help us grow and repair our bodies. Fats keep us warm and protect our insides. Vitamins and minerals help our bodies work properly. Water helps our bodies stay hydrated and helps carry nutrients to our cells. It's important to eat a variety of foods to get all the nutrients we need. This is called a balanced diet. A balanced diet helps us stay healthy and strong.

Text:
Step 1: Think about how to explain 'nutrition' to someone reading at the Middle School level.
Step 2: Select appropriate vocabulary and sentence structure.
Step 3: Write a paragraph of 200 words that follows your plan. Use the provided question to help guide your writing.

Nutrition is like the fuel that powers our bodies. It's the food and drinks we take in that give us the energy we need to move, think, and grow. Our bodies use different nutrients, like proteins, carbohydrates, and fats, to do all these things. These nutrients come from the foods we eat. For example, proteins help build and repair our muscles and tissues, while carbohydrates provide the energy our body needs for activities. Fats also provide energy and help our body absorb certain vitamins. So, eating a balanced diet with a variety of foods ensures that our bodies get all the nutrients they need to function properly. This is what we mean by nutrition.

Text:
Step 1: Think about how to explain 'nutrition' to someone reading at the Middle School level.

Step 3: Write a paragraph of 200 words that follows your plan. Make sure to include examples and visuals if possible.

Nutrition is like the fuel that keeps our bodies running, just like how gasoline powers a car. It's the food and drinks we consume every day that give us the energy to play, learn, and grow. Our bodies need certain nutrients, which are like the ingredients in this fuel, to stay healthy. Imagine a colorful plate filled with different foods - that's what a balanced meal looks like! It should have fruits and vegetables of various colors, whole grains like brown rice or whole wheat bread, lean proteins like chicken or beans, and healthy fats found in foods like avocados and nuts. Remember, eating a variety of foods is key to getting all the nutrients our bodies need. So, next time you sit down for a meal, think about how each food on your plate is helping your body grow strong and healthy!

Text:
Step 1: Think about how to explain 'nutrition' to someone reading at the Middle School level.
Step 2: Select appropriate vocabulary and sentence structure.
Step 3: Write a paragraph of 200 words that follows your plan. Review and revise as needed.

**Paragraph:**

Nutrition is like the food and drink that keeps your body running, just like gasoline makes a car go. It's not just about eating whatever you want, but choosing the right foods to stay healthy. Imagine you're a car. You need different types of 'gasoline' - like proteins, which help your body grow and repair itself, and carbohydrates, which give you energy to play and learn. Fats are also important, but we need the right kinds, not too much or too little. Vitamins and minerals are like the car's oil, they keep everything working smoothly. So, eating a balanced diet, which means eating a variety of these nutrients, is like filling your tank with the best gas, keeping your body's engine happy and strong!

Text:
Step 1: Think about how to explain 'nutrition' to someone reading at the Middle School level.
Step 2: Select appropriate vocabulary and sentence structure.
Step 3: Write a paragraph of 200 words that follows your plan. Make sure your paragraph has a clear beginning, middle, and end.

Nutrition is like the fuel that keeps our bodies running. Just like a car needs gasoline to move, our bodies need food to grow, play, and learn. The food we eat provides us with energy, vitamins, and minerals. These are the essential nutrients our bodies need to stay healthy. Imagine if you only ate candy for every meal. You might feel energetic at first, but soon you would start to feel tired and weak. That's because candy doesn't give your body the balanced nutrients it needs. To stay healthy, we should eat a variety of foods from different food groups, like fruits, vegetables, whole grains, lean proteins, and dairy. This way, our bodies get all the nutrients they need to function at their best.

Text:
Step 1: Think about how to explain 'nutrition' to someone reading at the Middle School level.
Step 2: Select appropriate vocabulary and sentence structure.
Step 3: Write a paragraph of 200 words that follows your plan. Include an example to help illustrate your explanation.

Nutrition is what you get from the food you eat. It's like the fuel for your body. Just like a car needs gasoline to run, your body needs nutrients from food to work properly. These nutrients include vitamins, minerals, proteins, fats, and carbohydrates. Imagine you're building a sandwich. You need bread (carbohydrates for energy), cheese (protein to help your body grow and repair), lettuce (vitamins and minerals for overall health), and maybe a bit of butter (fat for absorbing certain vitamins). If you only put cheese on your sandwich, you're missing out on important nutrients. That's why it's important to eat a variety of foods to get all the nutrients your body needs.
